question: You layin' all this at my door? There's been a recession on. What are you trying to say to me, Grant? After 12 years, my job's in jeopardy?
answer: Tickets are in your coat. Itinerary and player profiles are in your briefcase. We got a 9:00am tomorrow in Philly with this kid Darnell Jefferson.

question: Looks like I've lost weight.
answer: This kid's the gamebreaker we've been lookin' for.

question: You're from E.S.U?
answer: Coach Winters has been telling me about you. I'm looking forward to seeing you when you come to visit. I'll be your guide. You are coming to visit aren't you?

question: You got that right. Thanks for showin' me around, Autumn. I don't meet too many females like you. You got a lotta class. Real efficacious. Maybe I'll check you out in the fall.
answer: I hope so, Darnell. Good night.

question: This guy do this kinda shit a lot? They never mentioned this in recruiting. I don't know... I left a lot of 'em blank.
answer: Don't worry, you'll do all right. Lotta people don't finish.

question: Yeh.
answer: What are you doin' with the trophy?

question: Coach Winters asked me to bring it to the meeting. I don't know what for. I'll see ya at the meeting. Take this for me, will ya? Hey, Autumn, hold up! What're you doing here? I thought students didn't come back for two weeks.
answer: I came back early to see a friend. I can't tonight.

question: How about tomorrow night?
answer: I don't think it's a real good idea for us to see each other, Darnell.

question: What's the matter? I'm not good enough for you all of a sudden? Too young, is that it? I'm not, ya know. They held me back a year.
answer: No, it's not that... I've got a boyfriend.

question: Did you have this boyfriend when you showed me around?
answer: Yes.

question: Yeah, well, it didn't seem to bother you then. I'm willing to overlook it now.
answer: I was mad at him.

question: For what?
answer: I caught him with another girl. A white girl.

question: And you're still with this nigger?
answer: Look, I got to get going, Darnell. I'm sorry. I didn't mean to lead you on. I'm glad you came here.

question: Wait a minute. I can at least walk with you, can't I? Nothin' wrong with that.
answer: I'm in a hurry.

question: Darnell Jefferson. Tailback.
answer: Ray Griffen. Starting tailback.

question: I know. That's why they recruited me.
answer: The two guys they recruited before you are handing out Gatorade now. Better start strengthening your wrist.

question: We'll see. Give my best to Miss Lilly.
answer: What the hell is that supposed to mean?

question: Good to see you again, gentlemen. Jefferson, either take off the earring or put on a dress. I wanna talk a little about what we're trying to do here. There are many highly respected people who feel football is about preparation for life. These people are full of shit. You see, football is not like life. It's better. More exciting, more intense, more fun. In life, people are always wondering how they measure up; whether they're getting ahead or fallin' behind. In football, you know. Every week you get a chance to show what you're made of, a chance to demonstrate the physical and personal qualities that all those poor bastards who can't play this game are left to agonize about. Last year we didn't make enough of those chances. Last year everyone felt we let the school down. Fuck the school. We let ourselves down. We let down a great tradition, a 120- year-old Line of Champions. Any football program worth the name is a special brotherhood, an elite corps of warriors, a select group of knights. That first time our starting unit takes the field, the first time we huddle up; that's our inner circle, that's our Round Table. If I were an upperclassman, I'd be real nervous about my seat, cause we got some very talented new-comers this year. Guys who want a place at the Table. This is the trophy one of our freshman, Darnell Jefferson, won as a Pennsylvania State High School First Team All-American. You know what this says to me? Not a god-damn thing. Everybody here was a high school All- American. Whatever any of you have done before is out the window. We're startin' over. Ground zero. The Table is empty. Are you ready? Don't worry, Joe's a tough kid. He'll be allright. Allright, move it up. Let's go, 15 yards, run the next play. Cut the necktie tackle horseshit. You think you're in some kinda highlight reel? He left you huggin' air. Target his guts. Drive right through his abdomen. I wanta see snot bubbles in his nose. I wanta see shit in his underwear. You injured, Jefferson, or just hurt?
answer: What do you mean?

question: If you're hurt, you can still play. If you're injured you can't. Are you hurt or are you injured?
answer: I think I'm just hurt.

question: How ya' doin'?
answer: Fine.

question: Little late to be workin' out, isn't it?
answer: Only time I could get in here when the football team wasn't usin' it.

question: Well, if it wasn't for the football team, might not be a weight room to use. You tryin' to firm up a little, or what?
answer: Don't need to firm up. I'm strengthening my knee. Had arthroscopic surgery.

question: Had my knee scoped once too. When you're finished here, maybe we could get a yogurt, compare scars.
answer: Sorry, I don't date football players. They're all full of themselves. I saw you on the cover of Sports Illustrated, so you're probably worse than most.

question: That's real open minded of you. So you won't consider doin' anything with me?
answer: No.

question: Well at least tell me what happened to your knee. What'd you do? Fall outa your convertible?
answer: You know, there's maybe one thing I'd do with you.

question: What's that?
answer: Tennis. I'll play tennis with you.

question: Tennis. You mean now? It's raining.
answer: Thanks for the game, Heisman. You took it really well.

question: What's this Heisman crap? I didn't say anything about being a Heisman candidate. I don't go around strokin' myself about it. So what's this shit you're givin' me?
answer: I... I'm sorry... I just figured you were probably kissin' yourself in the mirror every morning.

question: You figured wrong.
answer: So what do you want, an apology? I just gave you one.

question: I want a rematch.
answer: A rematch?

question: Some other sport. I took my beating. You owe me one. Either that or we go out.
answer: I'll think about it.

question: Hello...
answer: This is Joe Kane. What did you decide?

question: What? It's 3:00 in the morning.
answer: I wanta know what you decided.

question: I don't know... I couldn't think of any other sports I could beat you at.
answer: Then I'll pick you up tonight at 6:00.

question: Hey, Autumn.
answer: Hi, Darnell. What are you doin here?

question: My advisor says I need a tutor. Ya know, just to get me over a couple rough spots. I saw your name on this list. I figured if you couldn't keep my attention, nobody could.
answer: I'm sorry, Darnell, but I've already been assigned. You're gonna have to find somebody else. I'm tutoring Scott Sherman.

question: Not anymore. I asked Coach Winters to switch us.
answer: Coach Winters wouldn't do that.

question: Yeh he would. I'm a bigger prospect than Sherman. He's a lineman on the scout team. C'mon Autumn, you could teach me some real erudition.
answer: Will you stop using those big words. It sounds ridiculous.

question: What doya mean? I'm improvin' myself. I learn a new word out of the dictionary every day. Mendacious, pejorative, antithetical, commensurate...
answer: And you don't ever use them right. Pretending to be smart is not the same as being educated. Or erudite. It's just a con. And it makes you sound stupid, no matter how big a prospect you are.

question: We goin' on that?
answer: Yeh. I thought we might take a ride.

question: I promised my dad I'd never get on one of those.
answer: What are you, one of these trust- fund princesses? It's fine for me to play a game I don't know, but I ask you to try somethin' different and you hide behind your daddy.

question: All right. But we go slow. No cowboy stuff.
answer: This speed, o.k.?

question: Yeh, fine.
answer: Good.

question: Slow down, damnit. Joe... Joe! Joe, look out!!! How could you do that, you stupid punk? It isn't funny, god-dammit, you coulda killed us! You're crazy, you know that...
answer: Take it easy. I've done that a hundred times. No big deal.

question: Oh, yeh? Then why are you shaking?
answer: I don't know... I guess cause I've never done it with someone else on the bike.

question: You just wanted to scare me. Are you happy now?
answer: Yeh, pretty much. And the scream was even better than I thought it'd be. Every dog within hearing distance wants to mate with you now.

question: You come here a lot?
answer: Now and then. Why?

question: It's not exactly a campus favorite. This is almost like hidin' out.
answer: I like places where nobody knows me. This too low-rent for you?

question: No, my dad owned a place like this.
answer: Your dad? You mean he owned a chain of these?

question: Not everybody with a Southern accent has their own plantation. My dad could never afford to send me here. I learned to play tennis on public courts. Mighta been able to play pro someday, if I hadn't hurt my knee.
answer: So you're just a scholarship jock like me.

question: Yeh. You disappointed?
answer: No, I've just never been out with a jock before.

question: Is that what we're doin' here? Goin' out?
answer: I don't know. What doya think?

question: I think you're crazy for jeopardizing your scholarship and a pro future by jumping motorcycles off of highways.
answer: Just tryin' to keep my edge, Camille. The other guys look to me cause they think I'll do anything. I lose that, I'm just another guy, and we all get our ass kicked.

question: O.K., using the things we worked on yesterday, I want you to write a two or three page essay on some aspect of your life. Something other than football.
answer: Like what?

question: Your father, maybe. You could write about your dad.
answer: Don't know that much about him. He was off in Detroit workin' in a car plant when I was born. Got laid off, tried to rob a jewelry store to get us some money. He died in prison. Some kinda heart problem.

question: How about your mother?
answer: She was always workin'. Usually two jobs. Comin' home one night she stopped to get us some root beer. Got caught in a gang crossfire. Shot three times... died on the way to the hospital. You want me to write about that?

question: No...
answer: Good, 'cause none of it's true.

question: Jesus Christ, Darnell what a terrible thing to do to somebody. That's not funny. That's sick.
answer: Had ya goin', didn't I?

question: No you didn't. You just... How could you make up somethin' like that?
answer: Sounded more interesting than the truth. My mom took a vacation to Chicago when I was 12. Never came back. Don't know who my dad was.

question: Who took care of you?
answer: I started hangin' with the J.B.M., gang-bangin'... Did some time in the Hall. Reverand Wallace saw me playin' football on a juvenile probation team. Took me in, got me into high school. Only reason they accepted me was 'cause I could play football. Sorta like here. Football saved my life. I'd be nowhere without football.

question: Well, then... maybe you could write about football this once.
answer: Yeh, o.k... thanks. I've seen a lotta shitty things in my life, Autumn. That's why I know when I see somethin' good.

question: I dunno. Detroit and Buffalo.
answer: Okay, Alvin, this is Mississippi State's offensive set. 2nd and 2 on our 24. What defense are you in?

question: Eagle. Zipper. Hero. Unless the set back shifts into the I.
answer: Good. How about here? 3rd and 7.

question: Okie. Thunder. Lion.
answer: What's your assignment?

question: What are you so worried about? You haven't lost your starting job yet.
answer: Just one. Take it easy, Darnell. This isn't a good time to push things. You're putting me in an awkward position.

question: Yeh, well, I got a little encouragement along the way.
answer: That kiss... it was just... a kiss.

question: Bullshit. You meant it. I wouldn't be standing here now, everybody thinkin' I'm a stupid asshole, if I didn't know you meant it. I wanna see you, Autumn. Not in study hall. Not like your student. Like somebody to be taken seriously.
answer: I do take you seriously, Darnell, but I'm still with Ray. I can't just go paradin' around town.

question: I don't need to go paradin'. We'll go someplace different. Someplace nobody'll see us.
answer: God, why am I even considering this?

question: I'm gettin' a little sick of this asshole, Autumn. I don't like you hangin' out with him. It's embarrassing.
answer: I don't hang out with him. I tutor him.

question: Then have him get another tutor.
answer: I can't do that. I made a commitment to help him pass his qualifying exam. I can't bail out on him now.

question: What the hell difference does it makes? They'll grease him through no matter what he does. Nobody's ever gonna see his graduation. Don't tell me you're falling for this guy. He's just another gang-banger with speed.
answer: I just said I wanted to help him. What are you more afraid of, losing your girl or your position?

question: Maybe you oughta think about what you're in danger of losing.
answer: Maybe I will.

question: You're right, nobody would ever see us here.
answer: Yes, I figure the key is to go places only white people go. Next time we'll go bowling. Plus I saw this in Rocky. I never believed a guy who was supposed to be an athlete would skate that bad, but now I know.

question: Thanks, that was fun, sort of.
answer: You were pretty good for the first time.

question: Well, it's not really my first time. My dad took me skating once.
answer: He used to play ball for E.S.U., didn't he?

question: Yeah, how'd you know that?
answer: I saw his picture on the Wall of Fame. You got his eyes. Luckily, you didn't get his thighs. Make sure you mean it this time.

question: What are you doin' here?
answer: Couldn't sleep.

question: I was just sweatin' out some of the beer. I didn't go home with her. I thought about it... but I didn't.
answer: You drink too much.

question: Yeh.
answer: Why didn't you?

question: Why didn't I what?
answer: Go home with her?

question: I don't know... I guess I figured maybe there was somethin' goin' on between you and me.
answer: Then why'd you pick her up in the first place?

question: I was drunk... I needed some company.
answer: Company? Yeh, I can see you havin' a real far-ranging discussion with Sheri.

question: I mean, ya know, physical company... I was... I just needed to pounce on somebody I guess.
answer: Why can't you pounce on me? Aren't I good enough to pounce on?

question: Well, you're more conservative... classier... you're not that kinda girl...
answer: How do you know? You've never slept with me. What makes you think she's such a great ride? I'm prettier, my legs are longer... I've got better tits. Why would you go to her, when you have me?

question: I didn't know I had you.
answer: Well you do. You shoulda looked for me at the library, or don't you ever go there?

question: I go there. I got a 3.2 in Political Science. I just don't go there on Saturday nights.
answer: I have a paper due Monday. What'de she do? Sit on your lap or just give you the nail-me stare?

question: Coach, we, ah... got a problem with Bobby Collins.
answer: Yeh...

question: He talked... a friend... into taking a test for him and got caught. They had a new T.A. in there...
answer: What's the penalty?

question: Well, the rules say automatic expulsion for both of them.
answer: Fortunately, we've got friends on the Board of Regents. I think we can beat this if we really go to bat for him. We got Mack off when he turned in that other guys term paper. But what kinda idiot would do something like that?

question: Well, I guess Bobby figured he was gonna flunk...
answer: I don't mean Bobby. I mean what kinda guy would be dumb enough to take a test for him?

question: Uh, well... it wasn't a guy.
answer: A girl? Typical Collins. He must have banged her until she couldn't think straight. Who was it?

question: It was... Louanne.
answer: Jesus, Louanne, how could you be so stupid?

question: Jesus, Louanne, how could you be so stupid?
answer: I... he was behind, he needed help. I'm sorry. I just...

question: Sorry! You're sorry! You've destroyed my credibility at the University, my authority with the players... Christ, it looks like I'm running a dirty program. And Collins of all people! What the hell's the matter with you, Louanne?
answer: I don't know... I thought he... loved me...

question: Loved you? He loves anything that winks back, the little rat bastard. And what are you gonna do for school now? I use my influence to get you back in, it'll stink to high hell. The press'll crucify me.
answer: I'll get in someplace.

question: God, Louanne, I told you to stay away from my players. That was my cardinal rule, stay away from the damn players...
answer: They've always been good enough for you. Good enough to devote your life to. Why aren't they good enough for me? Or are they too good?

question: You're changing the subject, Louanne. We're talkin' about you breakin' the rules.
answer: Didn't you ever break the rules just a little? Didn't you tell me once that 90 per cent of the schools obey the NCAA rules, and the other 10 per cent go to bowl games? Was that just a joke?

question: You seen this? You got a D on your math test.
answer: Yeh, I kinda figured that. I had some trouble on this last part...

question: We went over that last week, Darnell. What is this time we spend in here? Just a joke to you? I don't even think you've been listening to me.
answer: I've been listening to you, baby...

question: Don't call me baby. I thought you wanted to learn. But if all you wanta do is fake your way through, then get another tutor to waste time with.
answer: C'mon, Autumn, we just had a good time, and now you're gettin' all nuts behind this. It's just one test.

question: So far, it's the only test. I want you to study this whole chapter. By yourself, without me here. When I come back, we'll discuss it. Be ready to do problems based on it.
answer: Whatever you say, Teach. I don't wish to be cast in a pejorative light, so I'm dedicating myself to achieving on a level more commensurate with my abilities.

question: No, I don't really think too much about that kinda thing.
answer: Your parents comin' to the game tomorrow?

question: My mom's dead. My dad has never seen me play.
answer: Why not?

question: Guess he's not that interested in football.
answer: But you're one of the best players in the country.

question: He's just not into it, o.k.?
answer: O.k. What's goin' on, Joe? You ask me out here, like you wanta talk about somethin', then you don't say anything. You worried about tomorrow?

question: No... I'm worried about the days after that. I just. I don't know... I feel like tomorrow's gonna be my last game. I want to stay up, make the time go slow.
answer: Why would it be your last game? You afraid of getting hurt?

question: No, that'd be a relief. Then, at least, I wouldn't be a failure.
answer: Joe, why are you thinking like this? Why would you be a failure? You're having a great year, you're a Heisman Trophy candidate, you got millions of dollars waiting for you in the pros.

question: How do you know what's waiting for me? You don't know me at all.
answer: I don't know you? How can you say that?

question: Because you wouldn't be here now if you did. You only know the guy that's supposed to make millions in the pros.
answer: Is that what you think? That I'm with you for the money?

question: Why else?
answer: Fuck you, Joe. I don't give a shit about your money. I don't even give a shit about football. And you know what? Maybe you're right, maybe I don't know you. Joe! Joe! My god, Joe, what are you doing? No! No! God Joe, oh god, are you allright?

question: Yeh, just got some dirt in my teeth. Guess you've really seen the dark side now, huh? You should've gotten out while you had the chance. Before it all goes to hell.
answer: I don't wanta get out, damnit. What's wrong Joe? Why would it all go to hell?

question: I'm a Kane, Camille. That's all it takes. We're cut out to be drunks and fuck-ups. We never live up to expectations. It's in our blood. My dad, brothers, uncles -- we all drink and sooner or later we all fuck up. My dad went the longest. Waited till he was playin' triple A ball, before he hit the wall. Sometimes I feel like I'm just waiting for my turn. The better I do, the closer it gets.
answer: You're not like them, you can beat all that. You can stop drinking, you can break the chain.

question: If I gave up that, I wouldn't be much of a football player. And if I wasn't a football player, what would I be?
answer: You'de still be Joe. And I'd still love you.

question: Hey, Autumn.
answer: Hi, Darnell.

question: Is this your dad?
answer: Yes...

question: Oh really? In what?
answer: Math and English.

question: Ah. Well, stay on top of that, Darnell. I'd have been in real trouble if I hadn't gotten my degree. I played ball once. Hurt my knee.
answer: Yeh, I know...

question: I used to put a copy of my report card inside the webbing of my helmet to remind me that college was more important than football.
answer: Good idea. Well, I gotta get goin'. Nice to meet you Mr. Haley.

question: Nice to meet you, Darnell.
answer: See you around, Autumn.

question: Hello, yeh... What?!
answer: It looks like this will blow over. The girl's father is a big booster, contributed a lotta money. So he said they won't go to the press.

question: He said that? The father?
answer: Yeh, he's not exactly happy about all this, but he doesn't wanta hurt the program.

question: We're still gonna have to suspend Lattimer. He's outa control, Lyle. We can't ignore this anymore. I don't know what pisses me off more -- that he's juicin' or that he's doin' such a shitty job of hidin' it. Yeh, but we can't sit and wait till he kills somebody. I hate to lose him as much as you do, but we gotta clean him up before he does somethin' that lands the whole program on probation. Plus, we have to take some action or the girl's dad is gonna start havin' second thoughts. I don't care how many checks he's written.
answer: So what do we do?

question: Bring him down here.
answer: Three games? Why so many?

question: You oughta be grateful I didn't suspend you for the whole year.
answer: What are you gonna give as the reason?

question: We'll say you've got a hamstring pull.
answer: Thank you, Coach.

question: Don't thank me. During those three weeks, you better kick the roids, cause when you come back I'm gonna personally test you before every game. No N.C.A.A. shit either. I'm gonna watch the piss go into the bottle. You got that?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You know that guy? Then why you smilin' at him? So what? So you go and smile at him? You been lookin' at my girlfriend?
answer: I don't know. Which one is she?

question: Wise guy, huh? Mr. bigtime quarterback. The one who choked his ass off today. You got nothin' better to do then look at my girlfriend? Hey, Heisman, I'm talkin' to you. You too good to talk to me?
answer: I'm not even interested in talkin' to you.

question: Oh shit...
answer: What is it now?... Oh Jesus...

question: The guy went for me first. What was I supposed to do?
answer: Doesn't make any difference. It made the papers, all the wire services. The guy had to go to the hospital. Worst of all they got you on drunk driving. You had a blood alcohol level .50 above the legal limit. We can't smooth that over, Joe. It'd look like we were sprayin' Pledge on bird shit. We had to agree to send you to Rehab.

question: Rehab? I'll be a god-damn joke. You can't do this to me.
answer: It was the only way we could get them to drop the assault and D.W.I. You go to trial on those, we lose you for a year, and risk NCAA investigation. C'mon, lotsa athletes have been through Rehab.

question: Not in the middle of the season. Not in the middle of a Heisman campaign.
answer: You'll only miss four games. You'll be back in time for the last one, Georgia Tech, and a Bowl if we get there. Plus, you've still got your senior year.

question: Yeh, but what will I come back as? What kinda player?
answer: Don't worry, you'll still be the Man. You'll still be the leader of this team.

question: I'm sorry, Coach.
answer: These things happen. Fuckin' kids.

question: Darnell, wait. C'mon Darnell, I wanta talk to you. Where you been, I been callin' you?
answer: Been busy.

question: Darnell, I'm sorry about Saturday. It was an awkward situation.
answer: It wasn't awkward. It was educational. I realized how you see me. I'm good enough to tutor, to go places with, but not to tell your father about.

question: That's not it. It's just that my father expects me to be with somebody like Ray. He wouldn't understand us.
answer: Why not?

question: I don't know... he likes Ray cause...
answer: He's a good student, he acts right... he doesn't need football. He's class and I'm not, right?

question: I didn't say that.
answer: You don't have to, Autumn. I'm everything your dad used to be and don't want you fallin' back into.

question: Darnell...
answer: You were right before, Autumn. I should have another tutor. Thanks for everything you did for me.

question: Four fuckin' weeks? Shit, the defense is gonna have to pitch shutouts now... and you're gone for 3. What the hell did you take that shit for?
answer: Nobody seemed to mind when I was knockin' people's dicks in the dirt.

question: I bust chops too. I don't have to get all fucked up.
answer: Not everybody has the ability you do, Alvin. You do what you have to do to play.

question: I been talkin' to Chancellor Wilson...
answer: What's he wanta do now, cut practice down to once a week?

question: No, he's happy with the way the season's gone so far. The Alumni have pretty much stayed off his back, but with Joe out now, it could all be up for grabs again.
answer: He thinks he's gonna have trouble marchin' the ball down the old fund- raisin' board, huh?

question: The facts are, all we have left are freshman quarterbacks, and nothin' I saw at practice today, convinced me that any of them are ready to step in.
answer: What are you sayin?

question: We gotta get Bobby Collins back.
answer: Wilson say that?

question: He didn't have to.
answer: Forget it, Galen, Collins is no All- Star either.

question: Yeh, but he's good enough to get us a split of the next four games.
answer: Look, just because you're Wilson's boy all of a sudden, doesn't mean I'm gonna let him make me look like a fuckin' whore.

question: I think it's also instructive to look at some of the courses this young man has taken. Beginning Golf, Voice and Speech Improvement... In what, Swimming Pool Management?
answer: I don't know much about all this other stuff, but I do know the punishment should fit the crime. Cheating's bad, but I don't think it deserves a life sentence. Here's one of those athletes who takes college level courses, who wants to graduate. I think Bobby Collins made a big mistake, but he's already been suspended for several weeks. He's served his time. I think he deserves a second chance.

question: Like Alvin Mack? We gave him a second chance and since he's had 5 incompletes, 4 withdrawals and still reads at a fourth grade level. You're using his body to make money for the Athletic Department -- you, yourself, are making three times what the Chancellor is -- but obviously no one is making an effort to see that this kid gets an education.
answer: He's helpin' to pay for your physics lab too. If you're willin' to go without a new office, maybe I could hold him out a few games. Save his body.

question: Most of my players are farm boys, inner-city kids. Football is their deliverance.
answer: Deliverance from what? A valid education?

question: You throw Bobby Collins and Alvin out, you take away their futures. In Alvin's case you probably cost him a couple million dollars in the pros.
answer: But this is not a football vocational school. It's an Institute of Higher Learning.

question: Yeh, but when was the last time 80,000 people showed up to watch a kid do a chemistry experiment? Yes, sir, I can.
answer: Another case like this, I'll take it all the way up to the Governor.

question: Hey, Louanne, how ya' doin?
answer: Fine, Bud, ya know. Goin to J.C., hopin' to get back in here next year. Just came by to give Bobby some laundry I did for him.

question: You two seein' each other again?
answer: Yeh, he was even talking about us gettin' a place off campus together, until he got reinstated. I don't know how I woulda told my dad.

question: Ah, Louanne... I wouldn't go in there right now.
answer: Why not? Ah. Guess I'm pretty stupid when it comes to men. I never learn, do I?

question: I think maybe men are just stupid when it comes to you. If you ever feel like, ya know, just talkin' sometime, gettin' a beer -- let me know. My schedule's pretty open.
answer: Thanks, Bud Give him these, will ya?

question: You look good, Alvin.
answer: Yeh, I feel o.k.

question: Any of the guys been down yet?
answer: They called.

question: Hell, you know how football players are about hospitals and injuries.
answer: Yeh. I'm never gonna play again, am I?

question: Hello, Camille.
answer: Hello, Joe. You allright now?

question: Yeh... yeh, I think so.
answer: Good, I'm happy for you.

question: Camille, hold on, O.K.? I'm sorry that I didn't want... that I couldn't see you.
answer: You couldn't even talk to me. What happened to "there's somethin' goin' on between you and me"?

question: C'mon, Camille, I was embarrassed. I couldn't... I couldn't understand why anybody would wanta talk to me. Camille! How ya doin', Dad? No.
answer: I heard about your little set-to. They had it on the news here.

question: Yeh, they sent me to rehab.
answer: We know what that's worth. Your brother's been through it three times. So what are you doin' here?

question: I've been thinking about some things, Dad.
answer: That's what that damn rehab'll do. Make you think about a lotta things you can't do nothing' about.

question: I kinda been wonderin' why you never came to any of my games. All those years.
answer: Oh, I don't know. I guess I didn't wanta make you nervous. You mighta tried too hard and screwed up.

question: Or I mighta done real well. Which woulda been harder on you, Dad?
answer: What do you mean?

question: Mighta made you feel bad. Like maybe it wasn't written someplace that we all gotta go on our ass. Like maybe you coulda done somethin' more, if you'de tried a little harder.
answer: Or maybe I didn't wanta see you gettin' all excited, all pumped up with pride, when I knew one day it would all come crashin' down. Just like it did.

question: I think I spent the last couple years hopin' I'd die before that day. But you know what Dad? That day came and I'm still here. And I got one more game this year. I don't know how well I'll play or even how much, but I want you there.
answer: How would you feel introducing your drunk dad to all your friends? You think about that?

question: I could live with it, if you could. Here's a ticket. Section 2, Row 6. Fifty yard line. If you don't come, I'll never ask you again.
answer: O.K., Joey. And good luck.

question: Hey, Autumn. How's Ray?
answer: Don't know. Haven't seen him since the night I saw you. He'd been goin' out.

question: Monica Lambert.
answer: You knew? Why didn't you tell me?

question: Didn't wanta win you over that way.
answer: I just wondered how your studying was comin'. You ready for tomorrow?

question: The test? I hope so. I been workin' pretty hard.
answer: Good... I talked to my dad last night.

question: Oh, yeah? How's he doin?
answer: Fine. We talked about you.

question: What did you say?
answer: I told him I'd gone out with you... I told him I wished I could still go bowling.

question: He's worse than that. He's outa shape. All right, that's enough for today. Practice is cancelled. Everybody off the field, but Kane. C'mon what the hell are you standin' around lookin' at? Get outa here. Didn't do much while you were in there, did ya?
answer: Well, we didn't exactly have a team...

question: You could've worked out on your own.
answer: I had some other things to worry about...

question: Well, we're gonna make up for lost time. We'll start by hoppin' the steps.
answer: Hoppin' the steps?! What, you're gonna punish me now.

question: Don't talk back to me, Joe. I'll kick your ass. I went easy on you, 'cause you had to get through detox, but that's out to sea now. You let this team down; you let this program down. Start those steps. Right leg. Now the left. 70 guys. 70 guys who busted their butts all year. Because of you they might not win the conference. Because of you they might not go to a bowl.
answer: I didn't wanna leave... I just screwed up...

question: You dogged on them.
answer: No, no I never dogged. I worked my ass off. I played hard...

question: Then you shoulda stayed in shape. Keep runnin', dammit.
answer: I always played hard. I gave my everything for you. When you came to the Center, I thought you were really worried about me. But you don't give a shit. We're all just a buncha sled dogs. If you had another guy who could throw, you'da left me in the fuckin' hospital. The only thing that matters is the program, the god-damn program.
